- Graph theory (I miss you George)

- Teaching skills

1109168063654625281.text: I am not telling you this for sympathy. I am telling you this because *your* comfort at *someone else's* appearance isn't and shouldn't be their highest priority.

1109168062325030913.text: I dislocate both shoulders multiple times per week. I dislocate my ribs...kind of always. I dislocate my hips not infrequently. And my ankle is never in place, so it's always in severe pain.

1109168057111531520.text: I am covered with bruises from running into things, and from falling down, and from falling while losing consciousness.

1109168056226467840.text: Oh, and I have a chronic, severe headache from trying -- and failing -- to make my eyes work.

1109168055060520961.text: My vision is rapidly degrading. I'm contemplating if I need to get a cane. I may be facing a forced change in career. And when you can't make out your own face or other's faces, smiling seems less important.

1109168053605068803.text: Let me smile, the way that you like, while telling you why I don't smile more. I'll keep smiling, not because I want to or because it isn't a problem, but because obviously your comfort at my problems is my highest priority.

1102753533135388673.text: It's full of what-ifs. The medical and disability systems will not hesitate to penalize you for not trying everything suggested by your care team, no matter how absurd, but they may also penalize you for trying something they didn't suggest.

1102753531004678144.text: Taking control of your diagnostic journey is a loaded path. Your have to recognize that doctors do not have all the answers, even though you were (and still are!) taught that they do.

1102753529809330177.text: The ability to go outside the system is a privilege. It requires finances outside of insurance, the time to do so, and the connections to make it happen.

1102753528286720000.text: Yesterday, after much deliberation, I took my health into my own hands after not making any headway with the medical system. A couple of thoughts...

1091152977715433477.text: Turns out, regardless of what the data is, we need to make sure our training data represents the population it is designed to serve.

1091152976540889088.text: The lessons published in the annals of oncology need to be extended to other types of imagery as well -- CTs, MRI, X-Ray, the works, or else we're embedding bias in systems that have the power to impact a patient's survival or quality of live.

1091152975517675520.text: When evaluating a system to identify skin lesions as cancerous, patients of color would have seen worse outcomes in AI-assisted skin cancer diagnoses because...the system wasn't trained on a diverse training set of images.

1091152974389366785.text: But, concerns about the intersection of machine learning and medicine go into systems that many would consider "impartial" (where have we heard *that* before...), like image analysis.https://www.medicalbag.com/tech-talk/ai-outcomes-machine-learning-dermatology-cancer-diagnosis/article/829378/ …

1091152973286256640.text: Oftentimes the language that they find in their records betrays stereotypical thinking on the part of their doctor. Women being "anxious" and "hysterical" comes to mind.

1091152972397056006.text: At the time, by and large, I had been thinking primarily about systems that were using data collected by medical professionals. Ask anyone who's requested their own medical records, and they'll tell you how their "data" doesn't correspond to what they expressed in the visit.

1091152971168137216.text: In this thread from last year, I went into why diagnostic systems that are enhanced with machine learning need to be extremely cautious to avoid amplifying the biases of the data collectors and thereby automating harm.https://twitter.com/juliaferraioli/status/997302296508760064 …
